bboxes.raw_text:
Dry beans - and their cousins,
dry peas and lentils - can be
used in a variety Of warming
winter dishes that are nutritious
and easy on the budget, says AIRS
nutrition experts.


These foods that grandma used
to simmer in an iron pot for half
a day can be stand-outs in the
modern HOUSEWIFE menu, with
cooking shortcuts and variations
ranging from the old Southern
favorite "hopping john" to a
company fare baked dish of cur
ried lima beans and pork chops.


They are real budget buy - a
pound of dry beans will make 7
to 9 3/4 cup servings land all
are substantial foods, good for
energy.


Dry beans, peas and lentils con-
tain calcium and B vitamins, es-
pecially thiamine, and are a rich

DRY BEANS, PEAS AND LENTlLS
TASTY FOR WINTER MEALS

PHOENIX, AriZ. The third
annual barbecue benefit for Sam
uel Gompers Memorial Rehabili-
tation Center. 72ll N. 9TH ST.,
will be held on April 10.


Repeat chairman of the event
that last year served more than
5000 people Is Mrs. Wanda Bick-
ford, Mountain States Telephone
and Telegraph engineering de-
partment employee.


Co-chairman Is Connie Wo,
Gompers board member and ow-
ner of the Bi-Lo Market. In
charge of barbecue pits again
will be Joe Donofrio, with Wood
row Johnson assisting.


Edward Sporleder, Maricopa
County chairman for the annual
fund raising campaign held by

BIRD ANNUAL GOMPERS


BENEFIT BARBECUE APRIL 18TH

the Center, will be chairman of
tickets and community resour-
ces.


Last year more than $4,000
was raised to help finance SER
vices at the Center which include
therapy for both children and
adults afflicted with cerebral pal
~, muscular dystrophy, polio,
arthritis, deafness, stroke, hear
Ing ailments. and asthma, among
others.


Rehabilitation program pro-
ddes statewide help in physical,
speech, occupational therapy,
psychological testing, audiology,
pre-school orthopedic, and pre-
vocational evaluation. >r


The Center also conducts ac-
commodation classes for the
states handicapped children.

The Phoenix police department
needs policewomen.


Police Chief Paul Blubaum said
he wanted high-caliber persons
who are interested in making
police work career.


Policewoman's jobs pay $3.50
to $3.50 a month.


Applicants must be a high
school graduate and 1t is pre-
ferred that they have supplement
tai courses in psychology, socio-
logy or related fields. They must
be FL to IS years old. S feet
4 inches to S feet, 10 inches,
100 to Us pounds.


Women will work in crime pre-
vention and deal mainly with
women and children. Marital
status Is not a factor.


There are now five women
in the Phoenix Police Depart
ment, two of whom have been pro-
NOTED to the rank Of sergeant.


Deadline for application is
Feb. 8.

source of iron - a cupful pro-
vides almpsrhalf of a day s needs.
They also supply protein, which Is
most useful when convinced with
the types of protein in meat,
cheese, or eggs.


USDA Leaflet No. 1916, "Dry
Beans, Peas, Lentils. ..Modern
Cookery" gives tips on soaking
and cooking and contains recipes
for casseroles, soups, stews and
salads, as we'll as a bean PURGE
that can be canned or frozen for
later hurry-up use as a base for
sauces and soups or as a meat
stretcher. Single copies of
Leaflet 326 may be obtained from
the Office of Information, US.
Department of Agriculture,
Washington, DC. 2O25O. Send a
postcard with your name and ad-
dress and the words Leaflet 1926.

MIR. Harold T. Schnurer, Phoe-
nix Branch Manager, Small Bush
ness Administration, announced
SBA and the Phoenix Public Ii
sbrary will cosponsor a one-day
work shop for persons planning
to open business or have re-
Gently opened some. The session
is free. The meeting will be held
in the auditorium of the Phoenix
Public Library. Mcdowell and
Central Avenues from am. TO
4 p.m,, on Tues, Feb. 4.


The purpose of this all day
workshop is to better prepare
individuals who never before
owned or operated business of
their own. Many dos and
"don' IS" will be brought to their
attention throughout the proceed
ings. Schnurer said, "SBA' s aim
IS to inform the potential BUSH
nessman Of the advantages in be-
coming his own boss while at the
same time pointing out the pit
falls in owning and operating a
business"


Interesting and important dis
cussions will be held on such sub
jects as financing a business.
record keeping, site location,
marketing, legal aspects of busi-
ness organization, regulations.
and. general administrative man
agement. Enrollees will be adj
Wsed of the need for seeking as
much outside assistance as pos
sible from such sources as ac-
countants, attorneys, bankers. IL
braries and Government.


Anyone interested in attending
write or telephone the Small
Business Administration at 2727
N. Central Ave., Phoenix, or
telephone 2ol-36ll.


STATE NAACP MEETS


Rev. l.. j. Harper, state
NAACP president reported that
a campaign to obtain passage of
the public accommodations bill
will be started by the states
NAACP branches.


He said, "In Arizona humilia-
ton stalks thousands Of Negro
resident and travellers moving
throughout the state when they
are denied a place to eat, or
Sleep"


He continued that public offic-
ials who refuse to support the
bill will be remembered on cleo
tion day.

Ideal for fund raising groups.
New Vending Machine Franchise.
Exclusive perfume dispenser
vends 25f tubes. This Is also a
good husband and wife business.

covered by inventory. Phone
264-4oO6 ext. 8.

CENTER. el7 w. Buckeye Rd.

SESSION FEB. 4TH
